data.title: Rediscovery of a syntype of Chalcocopris hesperus (Olivier, 1789) (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Scarabaeinae), a possible specimen from Captain Cook’s first voyage round the globe (1768–1771)
data.text:
Abstract

Chalcocopris hesperus (originally Scarabaeus hesperus) (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Scarabaeinae, Dichotomiini) is a common and unmistakable dung beetle species from the Atlantic Forest of Brazil, Paraguay and Argentina. In 2015, a neotype was designated for its valid name based on the belief that the original type series had been lost. However, the designation was invalid for failing to comply with Article 75.3.1 of the Code. Moreover, even if it had been originally valid, the neotype would now lose its type status for we found a syntype precisely where it was originally said to be, in the material of the Joseph Banks collection, now preserved in the Natural History Museum, London. We present the evidence supporting the recognition of this specimen as a syntype and designate it as the lectotype. The specimen, from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, may have been collected by Sir Joseph Banks himself during the first Cook voyage round the world (1768–1771), but we discuss aspects that might indicate that it may actually have been caught later and by someone else. Finally, we show that Scarabaeus hesperus was fixed as the type species of Chalcocopris not in 2016, as recently argued by one of us, but in 1998 by Olivier Montreuil. The data gathered and discussed here will hopefully prove to be valuable to anyone investigating the history and type status of specimens from the Banksian entomological collection.

Fabricius, J. C. (1804) [Autobiography]. • Hope, F. W. (1845) The auto-biography of John Christian Fabricius, translated from the Danish with additional notes and observations. Transactions of the entomological Society of London, 4 (1): i‒xvi. • [Hope does not inform when Fabricius wrote this version of his autobiography—another was written earlier, in 1798 (Tuxen 1967). We assume it was in the spring or summer of 1804 because [1] Fabricius mentions events in his life up to that point in time (e.g., his 1798–1804 spring visits to Copenhagen to see the collections of his friends Sehested and Tønder Lund, as well as the publication of his Systema Piezatorum in 1804), and, at the same time, [2] he says “this summer I expect the excellent Humboldt to return from South America”, and that eventually happened in August 1804 (Papavero 1971). Therefore, he certainly wrote it after [1] the start of the spring of 1804 and [2] before August 1804].

Planches. Genres 1 à 65. Paris (Desray): pl. 14. [Publication date following Bousquet 2016. Note that Olivier (1789c) mentioned having delivered to “eager” subscribers “several illuminated plates” in August or September of presumably the previous year, 1788, before going to London to study its entomological collections. Even if the identities of these plates are eventually retrieved and new names are discovered to have been made available on them—thereby, changing their publication year from 1789 to 1788— this will certainly not be the case of plate XIV and Scarabaeus hesperus, for Olivier only discovered the species in London, thus, after delivering the first batch of plates he was referring to]. <https://doi.org/10.5962/bhl.title.49479>.
